content: In the heart of Stenograd, where every move was quietly shaped by the omnipresent Behavioral Compliance Index, Marek Halden’s sudden death shattered the illusion of perfect order. As the once-silent city faltered, Lenart Kova, a council insider, unearthed damning evidence of the system’s betrayals but chose to erase it, believing in the possibility of a fresh start. He triggered Halden’s last message, broadcasting a stark ultimatum: restore the BCI, begin anew, or dismantle automated rule entirely. Debate spread rapidly, and, in the city’s first-ever open referendum, citizens voted overwhelmingly for transparency and direct democracy, ending algorithmic governance and welcoming a new era of collective self-rule.
